column3: Glycine is biosynthesized in the body from the amino acid serine, and can also be derived from threonine, choline or hydroxyproline and is degredaded  into carbon dioxide and ammonia and  into carbon dioxide and ammonia. Glycine is involved in the body's production of DNA, hemoglobin, and collagen, and in the release of energy. It is a protein precursor contributing significantly to collagen. it contributes the central C2N element to adenine and guanine (purin bases), and is a an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system.

column3: primary metabolic end products of leucine metabolism are acetyl-CoA and acetoacetate. Can be degraded into to isovaleryl-CoA. column3: precursor of the amino acid tyrosine and  catecholamines including tyramine, dopamine, epinephrine, and norepinephrine. Levels are (almost uniquely, with Tyr, among amino-acids) high during chronic inflammation or infections, as well those suffering from sepsis or septic shock. In particular, inflammation‐induced production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) may consume a significant portion of BH4, thereby leaving phenylalanine unmetabolized.

column3: Hydroxyproline is produced by hydroxylation of the amino acid proline and is, therefore, a post-translationally modified, non-essential amino acid. Main constituent of collagen and elastin. A deficiency in ascorbic acid can result in impaired hydroxyproline formation.
